etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in Edward Topsell (d. 1625), Church of England clergyman and author. From post-classical Latin perfrication-, perfricatio action of rubbing thoroughly or all over from classical Latin perfricāt-, past participial stem of perfricāre + -iō

definitions: The action of rubbing thoroughly or all over; vigorous friction, chafing, scouring; (Medicine) rubbing with ointment.
